content.description: Huge ledge to start out on. Actual route is probably only twenty feet.
content.protection:
For TR: Climb the Dihedral and set up an extended top rope. two quickdraws, maybe a sling.

 On lead: 4 bolts to anchor.

 Lead bolts and top anchor replaced in Dec 2018 thanks to the ASCA (safeclimbing.org).

content.description: An old toprope that now has hardware.[beta]Follow small pockets and features up to the crux below the bulge, then mount it and clip the anchor. Either make a tough clip at the 3rd bolt, or commit to getting waist level with it before clipping.

climbs.name: Transcendental Acts (Original)
climbs.fa: Jack Dixon & Tim Miller or Patrick Huntley & John Campbell ca. 1994

content.description: Sometimes know as Drop Double D's (Direct). Follows a bolt line up the face just right of a large crack. Start standing on the shelf just right of the first bolt, clip it from the ground before starting on the small face crimps. Pull through some hard face moves between the first and third bolt before reaching a rest pocket high left, from there progress up and right through the crux sections.
content.protection: 4 bolts + 2 bolt anchor. Top anchor (Mar 2019) and lead bolts (Aug 2019) replaced with SS glue-ins thanks to ASCA and Access Fund support.This line clips the alternate 3rd bolt on the right rather than the one on the left.

content.description: This route mostly climbs just left of the bolts. A variation can also be done climbing 6ft left after the first bolt and can be protected with slings on chickenheads and runnels.
content.protection:
3 bolts + anchor. Use your own draws when toproping.

 This anchor now has chains, thanks to CH!
content.location: About 30ft right of Alice on Acid and 10ft right of a tree.

content.description: The direct version climbs mostly just left of the line of bolts. It uses the left hand jug slot that extends from the crack on the left, as well as the 3-4 pockets a few feet above that. Those holds are off for the original line.
content.protection: 4 bolts and anchors. Replaced with SS glue-ins in 2019 thanks to the ASCA.
content.location: Just right of the two large vertical cracks on John’s Wall

content.description: This climb is just left of the dihedral. Work up the obvious line of bolts to a defined crux sequence just above the second bolt.
content.protection: 5 Draws. Top anchor replaced in Dec 2018 thanks to the ASCA (safeclimbing.org).

content.description: Crimpy climbing. The starting jug and few smaller edges lead up to bolt 2. There the thin crux guards the hanging bulge and finishing jugs.
content.protection: 3 bolts and 2 bolt top anchor (replaced in 2021 thanks to the American Safe Climbing Association).

content.description: climb onto the ledge to the right of Alice on Acid. move up the crack, with face holds. pull up and over the lip. Dirty, seldom climbed, but if you are bored looking for something new.
content.protection: standard rack, tri-cams worked well, be creative.
content.location: start on the ledge between Alice on Acid and Sumac Attack

content.description: Named so by JP because “the only thing that belonged on that wall were fools and flies”.2nd bolted line to the left of the Dihedral. Start at the big flakes working your way up with a couple hand foot matches and decent crimps. On the last major footing step right foot out to a small flake, small to decent crimp hands, pull up and reach around (crux) to a slope around the buldge. Reach up right hand to a decent hold and find the rest.
content.protection: 4 bolts + anchors. Bolts replaced in 2018/2019 thanks to the ASCA (safeclimbing.org).
content.location: Look for the big flakes and work left of the buldge. Optional start is 5 feet left working along another buldge.

content.description: Its all tough. Just right of Right Crack. Tough, rough crimps up to a pretty good dish, a tough side pull (crux) and mantle to the finishing hold.
content.protection: 4 bolts + 2 bolt anchor. Top anchor (Mar 2019) and lead bolts (Aug 2019) replaced with SS glue-ins thanks to ASCA and Access Fund support.

content.description: Not much to it, go straight up. Crux is under the small overhang but there are some fun hand jams.Previously known as The Dihedral or Accent Classic One, before the microwave sized block that previously sat halfway up the route was carefully removed so it would not fall off unexpectedly and cause injury.
content.protection: Cams and nuts. Can use the 2 bolt anchor on RoA to the left, and there is also a 1 bolt directional anchor (replaced with SS in Mar 2019 thanks to ASCA and Access Fund support).
content.location: Start is a big ledge at the base of a big wall

content.description: Go up the right hand crack. Slightly off-width
Not much to it, fun place to work on an off-width crack and using gear. Jugs all the way up.
content.location: You'll pass it cwalking down Johns Wall, two paralell cracks

climbs.name: Attack of the Killer Tomatoes (AKA Air Danada)

content.description: There is a powerful move just past the third bolt, but some people think the crux is the crimpy section to the first bolt. Maybe stickclip it your first time up. This might be the best line at the entire crag.
content.protection: 5 lead bolts. Shares anchor with Fools and Flies, to the right. Bolts replaced in 2019 thanks to the American Safe Climbing Association (Safeclimbing.org) and support from the Access Fund.
content.location: The left most route on John's wall. 3rd route on the bookend, left of the dihedral

content.description: A fun linkup - climb the harder start of Attack of the Killer Tomatoes directly into the crux and finish of Fools and Flies.
content.location: Climb bolts 1-2 of Killer Tomatoes before moving right to bolts 2-4 of Fools and Flies.You can optionally clip the 3rd bolt of Killer Tomatoes with a long sling.
